messageBody:
Anthony Grahn scripsit:

> - We've made several charts for several accents mapping lexical sets
> to QS letters. Which one should a foreign student of QS use: which
> English accent is the right one to learn?

Whichever is taught in his country and/or will be more useful for him
to learn.

> - We have spent massive effort accommodating accents spoken by tiny
> groups of English-As-First-Language speakers (there's a whole letter
> just for Welsh place names) but none at all to accommodate ESL
> accents. This even where a single accent is used by millions (eg
> native Spanish speakers). Would it not, from a purely rational
> standpoint, make as much sense to accommodate at least a few of the
> near billion ESL speakers world wide as to accommodate a few hundred
> thousand native English speakers with a rare vowel merger?

Mergers make for complications, but not extra letters, unless you
are going to assign a novel letter to the merged sound, which I
hope no one will want to do. Probably most ESL speakers have
mergers rather than splits.

--
